"How do you make an alert dismissable (so it has an ""X"" in the corner)?"	"add the .alert-dismissable class, and the close button:<br><br><pre style=""box-sizing: border-box; overflow: auto; font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace; font-size: 13px; padding: 0px; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; line-height: 1.42857143; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); border: 0px; border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px; border-bottom-right-radius: 4px; border-bottom-left-radius: 4px; white-space: nowrap; background-color: transparent;""><code class=""html"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace; font-size: inherit; padding: 0px; white-space: pre-wrap; border-top-left-radius: 0px; border-top-right-radius: 0px; border-bottom-right-radius: 0px; border-bottom-left-radius: 0px; background-color: transparent;""><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;div</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""alert alert-warning alert-dismissable""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span>   <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;button</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">type=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""button""</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""close""</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">data-dismiss=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""alert""</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">aria-hidden=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""true""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span><span class=""ni"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(153, 153, 153);"">&amp;times;</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/button&gt;</span>   <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;strong&gt;</span>Warning!<span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/strong&gt;</span> Better check yourself, you're not looking too good. <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/div&gt;</span></code></pre>"	
How do you add a link in an alert without messing up the styling?	"Just make sure the &lt;a&gt; in the alert's message has a class of ""alert-link"""	
What's the cross-browser issue with Bootstrap's progress bars?	They aren't supported by IE9 or below.	
How would you set up a list of videos or pictures, where the media is on the left and its title/description is on the right? &nbsp;(like a blog archive page, or YouTube search results)	"Use the ""media"" class to wrap the elements, floating the video/image to the left with pull-left:<br><br><pre style=""box-sizing: border-box; overflow: auto; font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace; font-size: 13px; padding: 0px; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; line-height: 1.42857143; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); border: 0px; border-top-left-radius: 4px; border-top-right-radius: 4px; border-bottom-right-radius: 4px; border-bottom-left-radius: 4px; white-space: nowrap; background-color: transparent;""><code class=""html"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace; font-size: inherit; padding: 0px; white-space: pre-wrap; border-top-left-radius: 0px; border-top-right-radius: 0px; border-bottom-right-radius: 0px; border-bottom-left-radius: 0px; background-color: transparent;""><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;div</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""media""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span>   <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;a</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""pull-left""</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">href=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""#""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span>     <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;img</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""media-object""</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">src=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""...""</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">alt=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""...""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span>   <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/a&gt;</span>   <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;div</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""media-body""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span>     <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;h4</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(79, 159, 207);"">class=</span><span class=""s"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(212, 73, 80);"">""media-heading""</span><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&gt;</span>Media heading<span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/h4&gt;</span>     ...   <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/div&gt;</span> <span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;/div&gt;</span></code></pre>"	
How would you set up a comment thread, article list, or other page where you need to nest different levels of media (like in a forum where you have people responding to other people's posts, and you need an avatar next to each of their posts, correctly nested)?	"Use the ""media-list"" class to wrap the media as a &lt;ul&gt;, with each level of the thread being nested as if you were nesting list items. &nbsp;Give each &lt;li&gt; a ""media"" class.<br><br><pre style=""box-sizing: border-box; overflow: auto; font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace; font-size: 13px; padding: 0px; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; line-height: 1.42857143; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; border-bottom-left-radius: 0px; background-color: transparent;""><span class=""nt"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(47, 111, 159);"">&lt;ul</span> <span class=""na"" style=""box-sizing: border-box; What are list groups, when are they useful, and how do you implement them?	"They're lists that look kind of like menus, but each list item can have lots of custom content. &nbsp;They appear to be mostly useful for menus, options, and displaying the status of different portions of the website. &nbsp;Here's the most simple one, which just looks a bit like a column of a spreadsheet.<br><br><pre style=""box-sizing: border-box; overflow: auto; font-family: Menlo, Monaco, Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace; font-size: 13px; padding: 0px; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; line-height: 1.42857143; word-break: break-all; word-wrap: break-word; What are wells? &nbsp;How do you modify how much padding they have around their content?	"Wells just add a box around your content to offset it from the rest of the page. &nbsp;The syntax is to just wrap the content with a &lt;div class=""well""&gt;.&nbsp;<br><br>To modify the padding, add the class well-&lt;size&gt;, where &lt;size&gt; can be xs, sm, md, or lg."	
Do a case type function with:<div><br /></div><div>d =&nbsp;{'spam': 1.25,&nbsp;'ham': 1.99, 'eggs': 0.99,&nbsp;'bacon': 1.10}</div><div><br /></div><div>choice = 'ham'</div>	d[choice]	
<div>get with error handling</div><div><br /></div>d = {'spam': 1.25, 'ham': 1.99, 'eggs': 0.99, 'bacon': 1.10}	d.get('spam', 'Not an option')<div><br /></div><div>d.get('celery', 'Not an option')</div>	
<div><div>if x is true then a equals y, else a equals z</div><div><br /></div><div>x = [2] # True | False</div><div>y, z = 100000, -999</div></div>	<div>if x:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;a = y</div><div>else:&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;a = z</div><div><br /></div><div>print(a)</div>	
<div><div>Refactor to one-liner</div><div>if x:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;a = y</div><div>else:&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;a = z</div><div><br /></div><div>Given:<div><div>x = True</div><div>y, z = 100000, -999</div></div></div></div>	<div>a = y if x else z</div><div>print(a)</div>	
get boolean value of ''	bool('') #=&gt; False	
What does `break` do?	Jumps out of the closest enclosing loop (past the entire loop statement)	
What does `continue` do?	<div>Jumps to the top of the closest enclosing loop (to the loop’s header line)</div>	
What does&nbsp;Loop `else` block do?	Runs if and only if the loop is exited normally (i.e., without hitting a break)	
Loop through and print each pair of tuples<div><br /></div><div>t = [(1, 2), (3, 4), (5, 6)]</div>	<div>for (a, b) in T:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; print(a, b)</div>	
<div>What code is needed to make this work:</div>from tests import test_1<div><br /></div><div>(tests is a folder, test_1 is python file)</div>	"a blank file named ""__init__.py"""	
Create a lambda function to add two numbers	f = lambda x, y : x+y<div><br /></div><div>f(1,1) #=&gt; 2</div>	
map takes which 2 arguments ______ &amp; _______	function<div>sequence</div>	
"test if object s is a string<div><br /></div><div>s = ""1234""</div>"	type(s) is str	
1st step in fitting a model	# Define model object<div><div>Model = EstimatorObject()</div></div>	
2nd step in model fitting	<div># Fit model to data set</div><div><div># &nbsp; &nbsp;dataset.data = dataset</div><div># &nbsp; &nbsp;dataset.target = labels</div></div><div>Model.fit(dataset.data, dataset.target)</div><div><br /></div>	
3rd step in model fitting	# Examine predictions<div>Model.predict(dataset.data)</div>

What is the difference between list.append() and list.extend()?	list.append(x,value) | x.append(value) | Appends value to the end of the list.<div><br /><div>list.extend(x,list) |&nbsp;x.extend(list) |&nbsp;Appends the values in list to the existing list.2</div></div>	
What is the difference between list.pop() and list.remove()?	list.pop(x,index) |&nbsp;x.pop(index) |&nbsp;Removes the value in position index and returns the value.<br />list.remove(x,value) |&nbsp;x.remove(value) |&nbsp;Removes the first occurrence of value from the list.	
What does del do?	del x[slice]&nbsp;Deletes the elements in slice.	
Create a dog class:<div>shares kind = 'canine'<div>creates unique</div></div>	<div>class Dog:</div><div><br /></div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; kind = 'canine' &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; # class variable shared by all instances</div><div><br /></div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __init__(self, name):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self.name = name &nbsp; &nbsp;# instance variable unique to each instance</div><div><br /></div>	
What is class variable?	A variable that is shared by all instances of a class.&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>Class variables are defined within a class but outside any of the class's methods.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Class variables aren't used as frequently as instance variables are.</div>	
What is operator overloading?	The assignment of more than one function to a particular operator.

What are generator functions?	coded as normal def statements<div><br /></div><div>but use yield statements to return results one at a time,</div><div>suspending and resuming their state between each.</div>	
What are generator expressions?	similar to the list comprehensions<div><br /></div><div>they return an object that produces results on demand instead of building a result list.</div>	
What does yield do?	sends a value back to the caller<div><br /></div><div>suspends the function,</div><div>yet retains enough state to enable the function to resume from where it left off</div>	
Give generator function below, create an instance.<div><br /></div><div><div>def gensquares(N):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; for i in range(N):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; yield i ** 2</div></div><div><br /></div>	x = gensquares(100)<div><br /></div><div>x.next()</div>	
Create a generator expression for squares of numbers	s = (x ** 2 for x in range(100000))<div><br /></div><div>next(s)</div><div>next(s)</div>	
Force generator to produce all results<div><br /></div><div>G = (c * 4 for c in 'SPAM')</div>	list(G)

What is a&nbsp;mixin?	a special kind of multiple inheritance.&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div><div>There are two main situations where mixins are used:</div><div>1. You want to provide a lot of optional features for a class.</div><div>2. You want to use one particular feature in a lot of different classes.</div></div><div><br /></div><div>provides limited functionality and polymorphic resonance for a child class.</div>

What is __mro__?	Method Resolution Order<div><br /></div><div>It returns a list of types the class is derived from, in the order they are searched for methods.</div>

A method always present for&nbsp;the Class, even without a instance.<div><br /></div><div><div>class Car(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; @staticmethod</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def make_car_sound():</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; print 'VRooooommmm!'</div></div><div><br /></div><div>Car.make_car_sound()</div>

<div><div>Select only variable = 'A' data</div><div><br /></div><div># Create mock time series data</div><div>import numpy as np</div><div>from pandas import DataFrame</div><div>import pandas.util.testing as tm; tm.N = 3</div><div>def unpivot(frame):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; N, K = frame.shape</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; data = {'value' : frame.values.ravel('F'),</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'variable' : np.asarray(frame.columns).repeat(N),</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'date' : np.tile(np.asarray(frame.index), K)}</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; return DataFrame(data, columns=['date', 'variable', 'value'])</div><div>df = unpivot(tm.makeTimeDataFrame())</div></div><div>df.head()</div>	df[df['variable'] == 'A']	
<div>Create pivot table by variable</div><div><br /></div><div># Create mock times series data</div><div>import numpy as np</div><div>from pandas import DataFrame</div><div>import pandas.util.testing as tm; tm.N = 3</div><div>def unpivot(frame):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; N, K = frame.shape</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; data = {'value' : frame.values.ravel('F'),</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'variable' : np.asarray(frame.columns).repeat(N),</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'date' : np.tile(np.asarray(frame.index), K)}</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; return DataFrame(data, columns=['date', 'variable', 'value'])</div><div>df = unpivot(tm.makeTimeDataFrame())</div><div><br /></div><div>df.head()</div>	<div>df.pivot(index='date',&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;columns='variable',&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;values='value')</div>

What are Python decorators and how would you use them?	They extend past python, and are functions that take a function as an argument and return functions.&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>A simple example might be a decorator that takes a function, prints its args to stdout, prints the return value to stdout, then returns that return value. <br /><br /></div><div>The syntax in Python is usually done with the @decorator_name above a function definition.</div>	
How would you setup many projects where each one uses different versions of Python and third party libraries?	virtualenv	
What is PEP8 and do you follow its guidelines when you're coding?	A coding standard, and I try to. pylint is a great help.	
<div>How are arguments passed – by reference of by value?</div>	through reference,&nbsp;

Why is the GIL important?	<div>Global Interpreter Lock&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>every bytecode execution is atomic</div><div><br /></div>preventing true multithreaded bytecode	
what don't you like about Python?	<div>dynamically typed (saftey and speed)</div>	
do you use tabs or spaces, which ones are better?	spaces, set in my IDE

mpID3	takes Matplotlib imput and produces in D3 (SVG)	
Glue	<div>explore relationships within and among related datasets. Its main features include:</div><div><br /></div><div>Linked Statistical Graphics. With Glue, users can create scatter plots, histograms and images (2D and 3D) of their data. Glue is focused on the brushing and linking paradigm, where selections in any graph propagate to all others.</div><div>Flexible linking across data. Glue uses the logical links that exist between different data sets to overlay visualizations of different data, and to propagate selections across data sets. These links are specified by the user, and are arbitrarily flexible.</div><div>Full scripting capability. Glue is written in Python, and built on top of its standard scientific libraries (i.e., Numpy, Matplotlib, Scipy). Users can easily integrate their own python code for data input, cleaning, and analysis.</div>	
Seaborn	statistical plotting library	
Faker	make up data	
scipy	science toolbox<div><div><br /></div><div>eg: scipy.optimize.curve_fit</div></div>	
Blaze	<div>pythonic way of handling distrubted/large data</div><div><br /></div>	
drop a column from dataframe	df.drop(['id'], axis=1) # axis=0 is rows; axis=1 is columns	
get common info about dataframe	df.describe().T	
broadcasting	describes how numpy treats arrays with different shapes during arithmetic operations. Subject to certain constraints, the smaller array is “broadcast” across the larger array so that they have compatible shapes.&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>&nbsp;broadcasting rule relaxes this constraint when the arrays’ shapes meet certain constraints. The simplest broadcasting example occurs when an array and a scalar value are combined in an operation:</div>	
exec is&nbsp;	a statement, not an expression&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>It compiles and immediately evaluates a statement or set of statement contained in a string.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div><div>exec 'print 5' &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; # prints 5.</div><div>exec 'print 5\nprint 6' &nbsp;# prints 5{newline}6.</div></div>	
eval	evaluates an expression (not a statement) and returns the value that expression produces<div><br /></div><div>Example:</div><div><div>x = eval('5') &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;#=&gt; x =5</div><div>x = eval(f'{x} + 6') &nbsp; &nbsp; #=&gt; x = 11</div></div>	
What is&nbsp;compile?	&nbsp;a lower level version of exec and eval.<div><br /></div><div>&nbsp;It does not execute or evaluate your statements or expressions, but returns a code object that can do it.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The modes are as follows:</div><div><div>1. compile(string, '', 'eval') returns the code object that would have been executed had you done eval(string). Note that you cannot use statements in this mode; only a (single) expression is valid.</div><div><br /></div><div>2. compile(string, '', 'exec') returns the code object that would have been executed had you done exec(string). You can use any number of statements here.</div><div><br /></div><div>3. compile(string, '', 'single') is like the exec mode, but it will ignore everything except for the first statement.</div></div>	
Reload the module. &nbsp;The module must have been successfully imported before.	reload(foo)	
How does Python work?	Python defers almost everything until runtime<div><br /></div><div>Variables just point to value at runtime, and each value's type is used at runtime to resolve what the run should do.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>your raw source code is scanned for tokens,</div><div><br /></div><div><div>these tokens are parsed into a&nbsp;tree representing the logical structure of the program,&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>ﬁnally transformed into bytecode.</div><div><br /></div><div>Finally, this bytecode is executed by the virtual machine.</div><div><br /></div></div>	
Check if a is a set<div><br /><div>a = [1, 2, 3]</div></div>	isinstance(a,set) #=&gt; False	
turn on interactive help	help()<div><br /></div><div>eg: keywords # List of keywords</div>	
Get list of keywords	help('keywords')	
Check if bool is a subclass of int	issubclass(bool,int) #=&gt;True	
fuzzywuzzy	Fuzzy String Matching&nbsp;	
getattr	returns any attribute of any object.	
"<div>add Moe using&nbsp;getattr</div><div><br /></div>li = [""Larry"", ""Curly""]"	"getattr(li, ""append"")(""Moe"")<div><br /></div><div>li #=&gt;&nbsp;['Larry', 'Curly', 'Moe']</div>"	
<div><div>add 'c' using getattr</div></div><div><br /></div><div><div>a = ['a', 'b']</div><div>method ='append'</div></div>	getattr(a, method)('c')<div><br /></div><div>a #=&gt; ['a', 'b', 'c']</div>	
"<div>print:</div><div><div><br /></div><div>A bear is a animal.</div><div>A duck is a animal.</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>A cactus is a plant</div></div><div><br /></div>things = [(""animal"", ""bear""), (""animal"", ""duck""), (""plant"", ""cactus""), (""vehicle"", ""speed boat""), (""vehicle"", ""school bus"")]<div>from __future__ import print_function</div>"	"<div><div><div>from itertools import groupby</div><div><br /></div><div>for key, group in groupby(things):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; for thing in group:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; print(""A {} is a {}"".format(thing[1], key[0]))</div></div><div><br /></div><div>****</div><div><br /></div><div>for key, group in groupby(things, lambda x: x[0]):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; for thing in group:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; print(""A {} is a {}."".format(thing[1], key))</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; print("""")</div></div>"	
<div>replace : with by</div><div><br /></div>book_info = 'The Three Musketeers: Aexandre Dumas'	book_info.replace(':', ' by')	
<div>Combine into a comma&nbsp;separated list</div><div><br /></div>result_list = ['True', 'False', 'File not found']	result_string = ', '.join(result_list)	
"Get mean for each year<div><br /></div><div><div>import numpy as np</div><div>import pandas as pd</div><div>import pylab as pl</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>df = pd.read_csv(""http://bit.ly/144sh7t"")</div></div><div>df.head()</div>"	"<div>from pandas import *</div><div># for each year, get the mean of each column</div><div>df.groupby([""year""]).aggregate(np.mean)</div>"	
What is an abstract way of thinking about filter?	filter(is_positive, old_list)	
What is an abstract way of thinking about map?	map(function, iterable)	
Test for membership<div><br /></div><div>Is 1 a member of 0-10?</div><div>Is 11 a member of 0-10?</div>	1 in range(10) #=&gt; True<div>11 in range(10) #=&gt; False</div>	
What is cloning?<div><br /></div><div>Give and example</div>	<div>Return an extact copy by using conversion into same type</div><div><br /></div><div>a = range(10)</div><div>b = list(a)</div>	
<div>a = range(10)</div><div>b = list(a)</div><div><br /></div><div>a is b #=&gt; ?<br /></div><div><br /></div><div>a == b #=&gt; ?</div>	a is b #=&gt; False<div><br /></div><div>a == b #=&gt; True</div>	
Cloning creates a ______ copy.	shallow	
Create a deep copy of a list.<div><br /></div><div>a = range(11)</div>	b = a[:]	
The formal name for __init__ is ________.	constructor	
In OOP, mutators ___________	change the variances of an instance.	
In OOP, accessors _________________.	only retrive the value of a variable for an instance	
<div>Get 1st five elements from generator</div><div><br /></div><div>def squares():</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; n = 0</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; while True:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; n += 1</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; yield n*n</div>	from itertools import islice<div><br /></div><div>s = squares()</div><div>list(islice(s, 0, 5)) #=&gt;&nbsp;[4, 9, 16, 25, 36]</div>	
Give a generator get the 1000th value from it<div><br /></div><div><div>def squares():</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; n = 0</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; while True:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; n += 1</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; yield n*n</div></div>	from itertools import islice<div><br /></div><div><div>s = squares()</div><div>n = 1000</div><div><br /></div><div>list(islice(s, n, n+1))&nbsp;#=&gt;&nbsp;1002001</div><div><br /></div><div># Python 2</div><div># islice(s, n, n+1).next() #=&gt;&nbsp;1002001</div></div>	
Create a dictionary that assigns the first 17 letters of the alphabet (keys) to numbers (values)	from string import ascii_lowercase<div><br /></div><div><div>n = 19</div><div>dict(zip(ascii_lowercase[:n], xrange(1,n)))</div></div>

What is set union in python?	|<div><br /></div><div>a | b</div>	
What is intersection of sets in python?	a &amp; b	
What is set difference in python?	-&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>a - b</div><div><br /></div><div>note: not symmetric, a - b ≠ b - a</div>	
What is symmetric difference in set in python?	a ^ b<div><br /></div><div>The set of elements in either a or b but not both a and b.</div>

What does a single underscore in a variable for a class mean?	attributes to be 'protected ', which are not meant to be used directly by clients	
What does a double underscore in a variable for a class mean?	'Private' attributes not meant to be accessible by a subclass

<div>Find engineers who are not managers</div><div>using an operator</div><div><br /></div><div>engineers = {'bob', 'sue', 'ann', 'vic'}</div><div>managers = {'tom', 'sue'}</div>	engineers - managers #=&gt; {'vic', 'ann', 'bob'}	
<div>Find all people in either sets</div><div>using an operator</div><div><br /></div><div>engineers = {'bob', 'sue', 'ann', 'vic'}</div><div>managers = {'tom', 'sue'}</div>	engineers | managers #=&gt; {'ann', 'bob', 'sue', 'tom', 'vic'}	
Explain this statement:<div>&nbsp;a = 4, 5</div>	tuple packing,&nbsp;<div>a = (4, 5)</div><div><br /></div><div>There is also tuple unpacking,</div><div>c, d = a</div><div><br /></div><div>Thus tuple swapping,</div><div>d, c = c, d</div>

<div>split the string using comma as a delimeter</div><div>sort them in alphabetical order (case insensitive)</div><div>combine them back into a string of comma seperated values</div><div><br /></div><div><div>s = 'al,fl,tn,ga,sc,ms'</div></div>	','.join(sorted(s.split(','))) #=&gt; 'al, fl, ga, ms, sc, tn'

<div>Who is in one but not both (use set method)?</div><div><br /></div><div>engineers = {'bob', 'sue', 'ann', 'vic'}</div><div>managers = {'tom', 'sue'}</div>	managers.symmetric_difference(engineers) #=&gt;&nbsp;{'tom', 'vic', 'ann', 'bob'}

Create an Egg class that has a set and get color method<div><br /></div><div><div>class Egg(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __init__(self, weight, color):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self.__weight = toGrams(weight)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self.__color = toRGB(color)</div><div>&nbsp;</div></div>	"<div>&nbsp;def setColor(self, colorname):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self.__color = toRGB(colorname)</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def getColor(self):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return toColorName(self.__color)</div><div>&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; color = property(getColor, setColor, doc=""Color of the Egg"")</div>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.1""><b>To exit vi and save changes:</b></a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.1"">ZZ   or  :wq</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.1""><b>To use vi:</b></a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.1"">vi filename</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.1""><b>To exit vi without saving changes:</b></a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.1"">:q!</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.1""><b>To enter vi command mode:</b></a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.1""><i>[esc]</i> </a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.2"">A number preceding any vi command tells vi ...</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.2"">to repeat that command that many times.</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move left (backspace)</a></pre>"	<pre>h<br></pre>	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move down</a></pre>"	j<pre><br></pre>	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move up</a></pre>"	k<pre><br></pre>	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move right (spacebar)</a></pre>"	l	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move to the beginning of the next line </a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.3""><i>[return]</i></a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">last column on the current line</a></pre>"	$	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move cursor to the first column on the                  current line</a></pre>"	0	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move cursor to first nonblank column on the                 current line</a></pre>"	^	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move to the beginning of the next word or                  punctuation mark </a></pre>"	w	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move past the next space</a></pre>"	W	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move to the beginning of the previous word                  or punctuation mark</a></pre>"	b	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move to the beginning of the previous word,                 ignores punctuation </a></pre>"	B	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">end of next word or punctuation mark</a></pre>"	e	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">end of next word, ignoring punctuation </a></pre>"	E	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move cursor to the top of the screen </a></pre>"	H	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move cursor to the middle of the screen</a></pre>"	M	
"<pre><a name=""A1.3"">move cursor to the bottom of the screen</a></pre>"	L	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move to the last line in the file</a></pre>"	G	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move to line x</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">xG</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move current line to top of screen</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">z+</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move current line to the middle of screen </a></pre>"	z	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move current line to the bottom of screen</a></pre>"	z-	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move forward one screen</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">^F</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move backward one line</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">^B</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move forward one half screen</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">^D</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">move backward one half screen</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">^U</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">redraw screen </a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.4"">^R or ^L (depends on terminal)</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.5"">replace character under cursor with next                  character typed</a></pre>"	r	
"<pre><a name=""A1.5"">keep replacing character until <i>[esc]</i> is hit</a></pre>"	R	
"<pre><a name=""A1.5"">insert before cursor</a></pre>"	i	
"<pre><a name=""A1.5"">append after cursor</a></pre>"	a	
"<pre><a name=""A1.5"">append at end of line</a></pre>"	A	
"<pre><a name=""A1.5"">open line above cursor and enter append mode</a></pre>"	O	
"<pre><a name=""A1.6"">delete character under cursor</a></pre>"	x	
"<pre><a name=""A1.6"">delete line under cursor</a></pre>"	dd	
"<pre><a name=""A1.6"">delete word under cursor</a></pre>"	dw	
"<pre><a name=""A1.6"">delete word before cursor </a></pre>"	db	
yy	"<pre><a name=""A1.7"">(yank)'copies' line which may then be put by                 the p(put) command. Precede with a count for                 multiple lines.</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.8"">brings back previous deletion or yank of lines,         words, or characters </a><a name=""A1.8"">before cursor</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.8"">P</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.8"">brings back previous deletion or yank of lines,         words, or characters </a><a name=""A1.8"">after cursor</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.8"">p</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">finds a word going backwards</a></pre>"	?	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">finds a word going forwards</a></pre>"	/	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">finds a character on the line under the                 cursor going forward </a></pre>"	f	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">finds a character on the line under the                 cursor going backwards </a></pre>"	F	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">find a character on the current line going                 forward and stop one character before it </a></pre>"	t	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">find a character on the current line going                 backward and stop one character before it</a></pre>"	T	
"<pre><a name=""A1.9"">repeat last f, F, t, T</a></pre>"	;	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">repeat last command</a></pre>"	.	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">undoes last command issued</a></pre>"	u	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">undoes all commands on one line</a></pre>"	U	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">deletes first character and inserts after                 second (swap) </a></pre>"	xp	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">join current line with the next line</a></pre>"	J	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">display current line number </a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">^G</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">if at one parenthesis, will jump to its mate </a></pre>"	%	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">mark current line with character x</a></pre>"	mx	
"<pre><a name=""A1.10"">find line marked with character x</a></pre>"	'x	
"<pre><a name=""A1.11"">Any commands form the line editor <b>ex</b> can be issued          upon entering line mode.          To enter:</a></pre>"	:	
"<pre><a name=""A1.11"">Any commands form the line editor <b>ex</b> can be issued          upon entering line mode.          To exit:</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.11"">press<i>[return]</i> or <i>[esc]</i></a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.13><b>SUBSTITUTION</b>         :#,#s/old/new/g          #        line number range          old        pattern to replace          new        pattern to insert          g        optional key for global substitution                  (multiple occurences of old on the same line                 will not be replace without this)   <p> <A NAME = "">copies (reads) filename after cursor in file          currently editing</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.13><b>SUBSTITUTION</b>         :#,#s/old/new/g          #        line number range          old        pattern to replace          new        pattern to insert          g        optional key for global substitution                  (multiple occurences of old on the same line                 will not be replace without this)   <p> <A NAME = "">:r filename </a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.15"">saves the current file without quitting</a></pre>"	:w	
"<pre><a name=""A1.16"">move to line # </a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.16"">:#</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.16"">move to last line of file </a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.16"">:$</a></pre>"	
"<pre><a name=""A1.17&quot;"">executes 'cmd' as a shell command.</a></pre>"	"<pre><a name=""A1.17&quot;"">:!'cmd'</a></pre>"

Explain:<div><br /></div><div><div>def make_adder(x, y):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def add():</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return x + y</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; return add</div></div>	<div>A simple closure</div><div><br /></div><div>local variables are captured</div><div><br /></div>a = make_adder(2, 3) #=&gt; 5	
What is the difference between tuples and frozensets?	tuples are immutable lists<div><br /></div><div>frozensets are immutable sets</div><div><br /></div><div>tuples&nbsp;</div><div>- ordered collection of objects,</div><div>- can contain duplicates and unhashable objects</div><div>- can slice</div><div><br /></div><div>frozensets</div><div>- functionality of sets - O(1) element lookups</div><div>- unions and intersections</div><div>- can't contain duplicates</div><div>- aren't indexed or slicable</div>	
nbviewer	view ipython notebooks in browser<div>without downloading and running</div>	
ast	Abstract Syntax Trees<div><br /></div><div>helps Python applications to process trees of the Python abstract syntax grammar</div><div><br /></div><div>can write programs that inspect and modify Python code, after the syntax has been parsed, but before it gets compiled to byte code.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>opens up a world of possibilities for introspection, testing, and mischief.</div>	
string	Common string operations	
re	Regular expression operations	
difflib	Helpers for computing deltas	
textwrap	Text wrapping and filling	
General calendar-related functions	calendar	
Container datatypes	<div>collections</div>	
itertools	Functions creating iterators for efficient looping	
functools	Higher-order functions and operations on callable objects	
operator	Standard operators as functions	
pipes	Interface to shell pipelines	
io&nbsp;	Core tools for working with streams	
fragile base class	"base classes (superclasses)&nbsp;are considered ""fragile""&nbsp;<div>because seemingly safe modifications to a base class, when inherited by the derived classes,&nbsp;<div>may cause the derived classes to malfunction.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>The programmer <b>cannot</b> determine whether a base class change is safe simply by examining in isolation the methods of the base class.</div></div>"	
The usual role of decorators is to _________ in code by consolidating common elements of_____________	reduce repetition<div><br /></div><div>&nbsp;setup and teardown in functions.</div>	
patsy	describe&nbsp;statistical models in Python using symbolic formulas	
Heuristic to handle text:	Unicode sandwich<div><br /></div><div>Bytes on the outside,</div><div>Unicode on the inside.</div>	
If each dict represents a row,&nbsp;<div>you could pass a ______________&nbsp;to pd.DataFrame</div>	a list of dicts<div><br /></div><div><div>record_1 = {'Date':current_time1, 'Player':'John','Difficulty':'hard', 'Score':0}</div><div>pd.DataFrame([record_1])</div></div>	
<div>Convert column names to lowercase</div>	df.columns = [c.lower() for c in df.columns] #&nbsp;Convert column names to lowercase	
Rename some columns	<div>df = df.rename(columns={'p': 'points',&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'gp': 'games',</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'sot': 'shots_on_target',</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'g': 'goals',</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'ppg': 'points_per_game',</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 'a': 'assists',})&nbsp;# Rename some columns</div>	
Changing values in a Column	df['salary'] = df['salary'].apply(lambda x: x.strip('$m')) #&nbsp;Changing values in a Column	
Applying Functions to Multiple Columns	<div>cols = ['player', 'position', 'team']</div><div>df[cols] = df[cols].applymap(lambda x: x.lower())</div>	
Counting Rows with NaNs	n_nans = df.shape[0] - df.dropna().shape[0]	
<div>Select non-NaN Rows</div>	df[df['assists'].notnull()] # Select non-NaN Rows	
start debugger in ipython	%debug	
Encapsulation	"the packing of data and functions into a single component<div><br /></div><div>objects encapsulate their state and hide it from the outside; outside users of the class interact with it through its methods, but cannot access the classes state directly. So the class abstracts away the implementation details related to its state.</div><div><br /></div><div><img src=""paste-871878361365.jpg"" /></div>"	
dataspyre	a Web Application Framework for providing a simple user interface for Python data projects<div><br /></div><div>&nbsp;like shiny for python</div>	
joblib	<div>Joblib is a set of tools to provide lightweight pipelining in Python.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>In particular, joblib offers:</div><div>- transparent disk-caching of the output values and lazy re-evaluation (memoize pattern)</div><div>- easy simple parallel computing</div><div>- logging and tracing of the execution</div>	
make discrete or nomonial data into features	<div>DictVectorizer class</div><div><br /></div>http://scikit-learn.org/dev/modules/feature_extraction.html#loading-features-from-dicts	
genism	Word2vec in python	
Refactor:<div><br /></div><div>if type(obj) is type(1):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div><div><br /></div><div>a = []</div><div><br /></div><div>if type(a) is type(list):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div>	if instance(object, int):<div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div>	
Refactor:<div><br /></div><div>if my_variable == None:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div>	if my_variable is None:<div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div>	
Refactor:<div><br /></div><div>if not len(my_list):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div>	if not my_list:<div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return True</div>	
"Refactor:<div><br /></div><div>if boolean_value == True:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return print(""Succes"")</div>"	"<div>if boolean_value:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;return print(""Succes"")</div>"	
get current version of python	import sys<div><br /></div><div>sys.version</div><div><br /></div><div>sys.version_info</div>	
Protected instance attributes should be in _________ format.	_leading_underscore	
Private instance attributes should be in _________ format.	__double_leading_underscore&nbsp;	
Class methods should use ____ as the name of the first parameter (which refers to the class).	cls	
Use ________ (if a is not b) instead of&nbsp;<div>_________ (if not a is b).</div>	inline negation<div><br /></div><div>negation of positive expressions</div>	
If you must do relative imports, use the explicit syntax _________.	from . import foo	
Imports should be in sections in the following order:&nbsp;<div>_________________</div><div>_________________</div><div>_________________</div>	standard library modules<div><br /></div><div>third-party modules</div><div><br /></div><div>your own modules</div>	
Each import subsection should have imports in _______ order.	alphabetical	
In Python 3, there are two types that represent sequences of characters.<div><br /></div><div>Instances of _____ contain raw 8-bit values.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Instances of ____ contain Unicode characters.</div>	bytes<div><br /></div><div>str</div>	
In Python 2, there are two types that represent sequences of characters.<div><br /></div><div>Instances of ____ contain raw 8-bit values.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>Instances of ______ contain Unicode characters.</div>	&nbsp;str<div><br /></div><div>unicode</div>	
To convert Unicode characters to binary data, you must use the ____ method.&nbsp;	encode&nbsp;	
You should be very accepting of __________ (such as Latin-1, Shift JIS, and Big5)&nbsp;<div>while being strict about your __________ (ideally, UTF-8).</div>	alternative text encodings<div><br /></div><div>&nbsp;output text encoding</div>	
Write to a binary file in Python 3	<div>open('/tmp/random.bin', 'wb') as f: # NOTE: '*b'</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; f.write(os.urandom(10))</div>	
Return the canonical string representation of the object.	repr(object) -&gt; string<div><br /></div><div>For most object types, eval(repr(object)) == object.</div>	
<div>slice out: &nbsp;['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div><div><br /></div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']	a[:]	
<div>slice out: ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[:5]&nbsp;	
<div>slice out: ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[:-1]	
<div>slice out:&nbsp;['e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[4:]	
<div>slice out:&nbsp;['f', 'g', 'h']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[-3:] &nbsp;	
<div>slice out: ['c', 'd', 'e']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[2:5]	
<div>slice out:&nbsp;['c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[2:5]	
<div>slice out:&nbsp;&nbsp;['c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[2:-1]	
<div>slice out:&nbsp;['f', 'g']</div><div><br /></div><div>a = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e', 'f', 'g', 'h']</div>	a[-3:-1] &nbsp;	
<div>some_list[start:end:_____]</div><div><br /></div>a[1:10:3]	stride<div><br /></div><div>take every nth item when slicing a sequence</div>	
The only gotcha is that the iterators returned by generator expressions are _______,<div>&nbsp;so you must be careful not to __________.</div>	stateful<div><br /></div><div>use them more than once</div>	
<div>print each item and label with 1, 2, 3, 4</div><div><br /></div>flavor_list = ['vanilla', 'chocolate', 'pecan', 'strawberry']	"<div>for i, flavor in enumerate(flavor_list, 1):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; print(""{}, {}"".format(i, flavor))</div>"	
SpaCy	text processing in Python and Cython<div><br /></div><div>All strings are mapped to integer IDs, tokens are linked to embedded word representations, and a range of useful features are pre-calculated and cached.</div>	
Automatically turn on debugger for next run of ipython	%pdb # Automatically turn on debugger for next run	
What sort&nbsp;algorithm does Python use?	Timsort<div><br /></div><div>hybrid between merge sort and inseration sort</div>	
<div>How to iterate through the key value pairs of a dictionary?</div><div><br /></div><div>colors = {'blue':(0,0,255), 'red':(255,0,0)}</div>	<div>for k, v in colors.items():</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; print('{}-{}' .format(k, v))</div><div><br /></div><div><div>#=&gt; blue - (0, 0, 255)</div><div>#=&gt; red - (255, 0, 0)</div></div><div><br /></div><div>or</div><div><br /></div><div><div>for color in colors:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; print(color, colors[color])</div></div>	
What is a local version control system?	A database of changes kept on the same computer as the files being versioned.	
What tool included in Mac OS X keeps patch sets on disk?	rcs	
Why are centralized version control systems used (versus local)?	To collaborate with developers on other systems.	
How is a distributed version control system different from others?	Every client has a full backup of all the data.	
Why was Git invented?	In 2005 the Linux kernel developers couldn't use BitKeeper anymore and invented Git.	
"What is the ""snapshot"" concept?"	In Git, the data is more like a stream of complete snapshots of a mini filesystem rather than a list of file changes like you'll see in SVN, Perforce, etc.	
Why are most git operations so fast?<br>	They happen on the local disk, rather than over a network<br>	
How does git maintain file integrity?<br>	Everything is SHA-1 checksummed and stored not by filename, but rather hash value of each file's contents.<br>	
What are the 3 git states your files can reside in?<br>	committed, modified, and staged<br>	
"What does it mean when a file is in the ""committed"" state?<br>"	The data is safely stored in your local database<br>	
"What does it mean if a file is in the ""modified"" state?<br>"	You have changed the file, but not yet committed it.<br>	
"What does it mean if a file is in the ""staged"" state?<br>"	You have marked a file in its current state to go into the next commit snapshot.<br>	
What are the 3 sections of a git project?<br>	the Git directory, the working directory, and the staging area<br>	
What is stored in the Git directory?<br>	The metadata and object database for your project<br>	
What is copied when you clone a repository from another computer?<br>	the Git directory<br>	
What is the working directory?<br>	A single checkout of one version of the project. These files are pulled out of the compressed database in the git directory and placed on disk for you to use and modify.<br>	
What is the staging area?	"It is a file in the git directory that stores information about what goes into the next commit. It is sometimes referred to as the ""index""."	
What is the 3-step basic git workflow?	1. modify files in working directory<div>2. stage files, adding snapshots of them to the staging area</div><div>3. commit, which takes the files in the staging area and stores that snapshot permanently to your git directory</div>	
What tool is used to get and set configuration variables that control how git looks and operates?	git config	
Where are the three places that git config variables can be stored?	1. systemwide: &nbsp;/etc/gitconfig<div>2. per user: ~/.gitconfig or ~/.config/git/config</div><div>3. per project: .git/config</div>	
What option do you pass to git config to modify system-level configs?	--system	
What option do you pass to git config to make changes for specific to your user?	--global	
What two commands are used to set your name and email specific to your user?	"1. git config --global user.name ""John Doe""<div>2. git config --global user.email ""john@doe.com""</div>"	
How do you check your git config settings?	git config --list	
How do you check a specific config setting, such as user.name?	git config user.name	
What are three ways to get help on a git verb?	1. git help &lt;verb&gt;<div>2. git &lt;verb&gt; --help</div><div>3. man git-&lt;verb&gt;</div>	
How do you start tracking an existing project?	git init	
"How do you get a copy of an existing git repository, say https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2<span style=""line-height: 1.1;"">?</span><br>"	git clone&nbsp;https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2	
What are a couple different transfer protocols used by git?	https://<div>git://</div>	
What is the difference between a tracked and untracked file?	Tracked files are all files that were in the last snapshot. They can be unmodified, modified, or staged. Untracked files are not in the latest snapshot or staged.	
How do you check what tracking state your project files are in?	git status	
How do you begin tracking a new file?	git add &lt;file&gt;	
How do you stage a tracked file that has been modified?	git add &lt;file&gt;	
Why is it possible for a tracked file to be both in staging and modified state?	"Because the staged version is the contents of the file at the exact time you ran ""git add"" to stage the file. You have to run ""git add"" again if you've modified it and want to stage the latest contents of the file."	
How can you view the status of files in a compact way?	git status -s&nbsp;<div>git status --short</div>	
What does A, M, and ?? mean in short git status output?	A = added to the staging area<div>M = modified</div><div>?? = untracked</div>	
What file is used to ignore some untracked files?	.gitignore	
What .gitignore pattern would you use to ignore all .txt files in the doc folder?	doc/**/*.txt	
How do you view the difference in content between what is changed but not yet staged?	git diff	
How do you view differences in content from what is staged and the latest snapshot?	git diff --staged<div>or</div><div>git diff --cached</div>	
How do you commit everything in the staging area as a new snapshot?	git commit	
How do you specify a git commit message inline?	"git commit -m ""&lt;message&gt;"""	
How can you skip the staging area for modified, tracked files when doing a commit?	git commit -a	
How do you remove a tracked file?	git rm	
How do you delete a file that has been modified and already added to the staging area?	git rm -f	
How do you remove a file from staging but keep the working copy?	git rm --cached &lt;file&gt;	
How do you rename or move a file in git?	git mv &lt;src&gt; &lt;target&gt;	
How do you view the commit history?	git log	
How would you see the last two entries of commit history and the changes in each commit?	git log -p -2	
How could you see some abbreviated stats for each commit in the commit history?	git log --stat	
What are some of the options to view the commit log history in different formats?	"--pretty=[oneline | short | full | fuller]<div>--pretty=format:""...""</div>"	
How can you view the commit history with an ASCII graph and abbreviated commit hash plus subject?	"git log --pretty=format:""%h %s"" --graph"	
How could you view the git history with dates in relative format?	git log --relative-date	
How do you view the history for author jdoe with keyword potato in the commit message made in the last two weeks that added or removed a reference to the function mashThePotato that were not merges?	git log --author jdoe --grep potato --all-match -SmashThePotato --since=2.weeks --no-merges	
If you committed too early and forgot to add some files, you can add them to the previous commit with this command.	git commit --amend	ch2
If you want to change your last commit message, you can use this command.	git commit --amend	
How do you unstage a file that was accidentally staged?	git reset HEAD &lt;file&gt;	
"Why is git reset considered safe without ""--hard"" option?"	It only affects your staging area	
How do you discard changes to your working copy of a modified file?	git checkout -- &lt;file&gt;	
How do you see which remote servers you have configured?	git remote	
How do you see all configured remote URLs?	git remote -v	
How do you add the git repository at https://github.com/paulboone/ticgit with the shortname pb?	git remote add pb https://github.com/paulboone/ticgit	
What are shortnames for repositories used for?	You can use the shortname in lieu of the whole URL, e.g. git fetch pb	
How do you get data from remote repositories?	git fetch &lt;remote-name&gt;	
What is the default shortname for cloned repositories?	origin	
How does git fetch affect your local repository?	It pulls the data, but does not merge or modify your working copy. To actually merge, it must be manually done.	
How can you fetch and merge on a branch that is tracking a remote branch?	git pull	
How do you share your project upstream?	git push [remote-name] [branch-name]	
"How do you see some info about a remote repository with shortname ""origin""?"	git remote show origin	
How can you rename a remote shortname?	git remote rename &lt;old&gt; &lt;new&gt;	
How do you remove a remote branch?	git remote rm &lt;name&gt;	
How do you list available tags?	git tag	
"How do you create an annotated tag with name v1.0 and message ""stable release""?"	"git tag -a v1.0 -m ""stable release"""	
"How do you see tag ""v1.0"" data along with the commit?"	git show v1.0	
How do you tag say checksum 0123abc with the name v1.0?	git tag -a v1.0 0123abc	
How do you share tags upstream?	git push [branch-name] [tag-name]	
How would you share all your tags upstream?	git push origin --tags	
How can you make your working directory reflect a specific tag?	You will have to create a branch from a tag:<div>git checkout -b [branch-name] [tag-name]</div><div>e.g.<br><div>git checkout -b version2 v2.0.0</div></div>	
"How would you create an alias for ""git commit"" to be ""git ci""?"	git config --global alias.ci commit	
Describe the common workflow	"<img src=""Screen Shot 2015-04-12 at 10.39.25 AM.png"" /><div>1. Instance model class</div><div>2. Train method</div><div>3. Predict method</div><div>4. Evaluation method</div>"	
What is stored in a git commit object?	* pointer to the snapshot of the staged content<div>* author's name and email</div><div>* commit message</div><div>* pointer to the commit(s) directly before this one</div>	
What is the git term for a checksummed file (particular version of a file) in a repository?	blob	
A commit object has how many parents for an initial commit?	none	
A commit object has how many parents for the 2nd commit?	one	
A commit object has how many parents if it's a merge of 2 branches?	2	
What is the name of the default branch in git?	master	
What is a branch in terms of git commit objects?	A lightweight movable pointer to one of the commits	
How do you create a new branch?	git branch &lt;name&gt;	
What is the name of the special pointer which tells you which local branch you're currently on?	HEAD	
What happens to the HEAD pointer when you create a new branch?	Nothing, it continues to point to the existing branch (such as master, if you haven't changed it yet). It does not switch to the new branch automatically.	
How can you see where the branch pointers are pointing?	git log --decorate	
How do you switch to a branch?	git checkout &lt;name&gt;	
What happens to the working directory when you switch branches?	The files are updated to reflect the last commit of the branch. If it cannot be updated cleanly, git will not let you switch.	
When using branches, how can you see the history of commits, show where branch pointers are, and how history has diverged?	git log --oneline --decorate --graph --all	
Why is a git branch cheap?	A branch is a simple file that contains the 40 character SHA-1 checksum of the commit it points to.	
How can you create a branch and switch to it at the same time?	git checkout -b &lt;name&gt;	
"Let's say you just committed your final change to your branch ""test"". Now, how do you merge ""test"" back into master?"	git checkout master<div>git merge test</div>	
"What is a ""fast-forward"" merge?"	"When you try to merge a commit that can be reached by following the first commit's history, git will simply move the pointer forward because there is no divergent work to merge together. This is known as a ""fast-forward"" merge."	
How do you delete a branch?	git branch -d &lt;name&gt;	
What is a merge commit?	When two divergent branches are merged, git creates a new snapshot and a new commit that points to it. A merge commit has more than one parent.	
How is git different in dealing with the merge base when merging branches?	Git determines the best common ancestor to use for its merge base, which is a lot simpler than many other VCSes.	
If there are merge conflicts with markers in a file that you manually fix, how do you then mark the file resolved?	git add &lt;file&gt;	
How can you use a graphical tool to resolve merge conflicts?	git mergetool	
How do you list all your current branches?	git branch	
What does the leading * character mean in the output of git branch?	It indicates the branch you have currently checked out (that HEAD points to).	
How can you see the last commit on each branch?	git branch -v	
How do you see which branches are already merged into the branch you're currently on?	git branch --merged	
How do you see which branches have not yet been merged into the branch you're currently working on?	git branch --no-merged	
"What happens if you try to delete a branch with ""git branch -d &lt;name&gt;"" that has not yet been merged?"	It will fail, and offer -D if you really want to lose your branch.	
What is the name used for a branching workflow where sets of commits graduate to a more stable silo when they're fully tested?<br>	progressive-stability branching<br>	
What is the name for a short-lived branch for a single particular feature or related work?<br>	topic branch<br>	
What are remote branches?<br>	Pointers to the state of branches in remote repositories. They are local branches that you cannot move.<br>	
When are remote branch pointers updated?<br>	They are automatically moved when you do any network communication.<br>	
When you clone a repository without any special parameters, what shortname is given to the remote, and what name is given to the remote branch, and what name is given to your local branch?<br>	shortname = origin<br>remote branch = origin/master<br>local branch = master<br>	
"If you want to use a different name than ""origin"" for the remote when cloning a repository, what parameter would you use?<br>"	git clone -o &lt;name&gt; &lt;repo&gt;<br>	
How would you share a local branch upstream?<br>	git push &lt;remote-name&gt; &lt;branch-name&gt; <br>	
"How would you share a local branch called ""badname"" as ""goodname"" on a remote called ""origin""?<br>"	git push origin badname:goodname<br>	
How would you set up a credential cache so that you don't have to keep typing your password for git push?	git config --global credential.helper cache	
When you fetch a remote branch, will it automatically set up a local branch with the same name?	No. You must either merge it or create your own branch from it.	
"Once you've fetched a remote branch, how do you merge it into your working branch? Say the remote is called ""teamone"" and the branch is called ""topic-a"""	git merge teamone/topic-a	
"Once you've fetched a remote branch, how do you create a local branch for it? Say the remote is called ""teamone"" and the branch is called ""topic-a"""	git checkout -b topic-a origin/topic-a<div>or</div><div>git checkout --track origin/topic-a</div>	
What are some other names for a remote branch that you've checked out locally?	a tracking branch<div>an upstream branch</div>	
If you're on a tracking branch, how would you fetch and merge from the correct server?	git pull<div>(Git automatically knows which server to pull from with tracking branches)</div>	
If you have a local branch and you want it to use a remote branch (say origin/hotfix) you just pulled down, how would you set it?	<div>git branch -u origin/hotfix<div>or</div><div>git branch --set-upstream-to origin/hotfix</div></div>	
If you have a local branch and want to change the remote branch it tracks, what would you do?	<div>git branch -u &lt;remote&gt;/&lt;branch&gt;</div><div>or</div><div>git branch --set-upstream-to &lt;remote&gt;/&lt;branch&gt;</div>	
What is the shorthand for referencing the tracking remote and branch?	@{u} or @{upstream}	
How do you see what tracking branches you have set up?	git branch -vv	
How would you get the latest state of your remote tracked branches (based on what's changed on the server)?	git fetch --all &amp;&amp; git branch -vv	
"How would you delete a remote branch (""serverfix"") from the server (""origin"")?"	git push origin --delete serverfix	
How would you take all the changes committed on one branch and replay them on another?	git rebase	
How does rebasing affect the commit history differently than a merge?	A rebase will make the commit history look linear/clean rather than a bunch of branch merges. This is often done to make sure your commits apply cleanly to a remote branch.	
How would you use rebase to apply master changes to branch b1, then apply b1 changes to master? The result being a linear history.	<div># method: 1</div>git checkout b1<div>git rebase master</div><div>git checkout master</div><div>git merge b1</div><div><br></div><div># method: 2</div><div>git rebase b1 master</div><div>git checkout master</div><div>git merge b1</div>	
How would you checkout a branch b1, figure out the patches from the common ancestors of b1 and b2, and then replay them on master?	git rebase --onto master b2 b1	
What one tip should you follow to avoid a drawback of rebasing?	Do not rebase commits that exist outside of your repository.	
What is the patch-id?	It is a checksum calculated by git that is based on just the patch introduced by a commit.	
If you have changes on commits that no longer exist upstream (due to a remote rebase), how can you pull in those changes and avoid conflicts that would happen with git pull origin/master?	<div>git fetch</div>git rebase origin/master<div>or</div><div>git pull --rebase</div>	
What is a good general rule for deciding when to rebase or to merge?	Rebase local changes you haven't shared yet in order to clean up, but never rebase anything you pushed somewhere.	
What are the four major protocols git uses to transfer data?	local, http/s, ssh, git	
What are two ways of cloning a repository with the local protocol?	git clone /path/to/git/project.git<div>or</div><div>git clone file:///path/to/git/project.git</div>	
Why would you choose to clone locally via direct path vs file://?	Direct path is faster<div>file:// will create a clean copy without extraneous objects or references</div>	
How would you add an existing repository (say /opt/git/project.git) to an existing git repository with shortname local_proj?	git remote add local_proj /opt/git/project.git	
What are the two informal modes of HTTP/S transfer?	"""Smart"" HTTP mode<div>""Dumb"" HTTP mode</div>"	
"What is the difference between ""Smart"" HTTP mode and ""Dumb"" HTTP mode?"	Smart HTTP mode can use authentication without ssh (easier), but also can be anonymous. It is the most popular.<div>In Dumb HTTP mode, the bare Git repository is served read-only like normal files from a web server.</div>	
"What are two ways of cloning /opt/git/project.git on server ""host.com"" via SSH?"	git clone ssh://user@host.com/opt/git/project.git<div>or</div><div>git clone user@host.com:/opt/git/project.git</div>	
What port does the Git protocol use?	9418	
What are some characteristics of the git protocol?	* no authentication<div>* very fast</div><div>* requires it's own daemon</div>	
What file must be created in order for a repository to be served over the git protocol?	git-daemon-export-ok	
"What is a ""bare repository""?"	A repository that doesn't contain a working directory	
How would you export an existing repository (say called my_project) into a new bare repository (say called my_project.git)?	git clone --bare my_project my_project.git	
How would you use scp to copy a bare repository my_project.git to host.com under /opt/git?	scp -r my_project.git user@host.com:/opt/git	
How would you make a bare repository (say /opt/git/my_project.git) group-shared?	cd /opt/git<div>git init --bare --shared</div>	
What is git-shell?	A tool used to restrict users to only doing Git-related activities by having a user's shell point to the git-shell in the /etc/passwd file.	
How would you run the git daemon with a base of /opt/git/ and repositories at /opt/git/ and allow the server to restart without waiting for old connections to timeout?	git daemon --reuseaddr --base-path=/opt/git/ /opt/git/	
What is the name of the CGI script that allows git to use smart HTTP protocol?	git-http-backend	
pickle saves as a 	byte stream	
get length of 'foo'	'foo'.__len__() # Pythonic	
<div>list = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']</div>print(list[10:])<div><br /></div><div>What is the output?</div>	[]<div><br /></div><div>not result in an IndexError</div>	
Refactor<div><br /></div><div><div>def extendList(val, list=[]):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; list.append(val)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; return list</div><div><br /></div><div>list1 = extendList(10)</div><div>list2 = extendList(123,[])</div><div>list3 = extendList('a')</div></div>	<div>def extendList(val, list=None):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; if list is None:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; list = []</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; list.append(val)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; return list</div>	
Python 2's basic original strings are called _____,&nbsp;<div>and they play a dual role in Python 2 as both ______ and as ______.</div>	8-bit strings<div><br /></div><div>ASCII text&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>byte sequences</div>	
Python 2 has two basic integer types:<div>1) &nbsp;__________</div><div>2) __________</div>	1) a native machine-sized int type<div><br /></div><div>2)&nbsp;an arbitrary length long type</div>	
Python 3 has a single numeric type: ______<div>(analogous to _____)</div>	&nbsp;int&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>Python 2's long type</div>	
how does %paste work	<div>1. Copy the lines you want to copy into IPython into the clipboard</div><div><br /></div><div>2. Enter %paste into IPython</div><div><br /></div><div>3. Press enter</div><div><br /></div><div>4. Profit!</div>	
Use default dictionary:<div><br /></div><div>d['mark'] = 'blue'</div>	from collections import defaultdict<div><br /></div><div>d = defaultdict(str)</div><div>d['mark'] = 'blue'</div>	
The most important thing about defaultdict is _______	they have default factory<div><br /></div><div><div>from collections import defaultdict</div><div><br /></div><div>d = defaultdict(str)</div></div><div>d = defaultdict(list)</div>	
subclassing	"the features of a single super class. &nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>A class acquires the properties of another class.</div><div><img src=""Single_Inheritance.jpg"" /></div>"	
A class is just ________<div><br /></div><div>It defines how something should be laid out,&nbsp;</div><div>but doesn’t actually fill in the________.&nbsp;</div>	structure<div><br /></div><div>content</div>	
instances are&nbsp;specific examples of a class,<div>that _________.</div>	contain all of the content	
curses	a screen-painting and keyboard-handling facility for text-based terminal<div><br /></div><div>perform common operations such as moving the cursor, scrolling the screen, and erasing areas. Different terminals use widely differing codes, and often have their own minor quirks.</div>	
What is a Counter?	<div><div>Elements are stored as dictionary keys and their counts</div><div>are stored as dictionary values.</div></div><div><br /></div><div>c = Counter('abcdeabcdabcaba') &nbsp;# count elements from a string</div><div><br /></div><div>c</div><div>Counter({'a': 5, 'b': 4, 'c': 3, 'd': 2, 'e': 1})</div>	
convert 2 to binary	bin(2)	
convert '11' or&nbsp;'0b11' to integer	int('11', 2)&nbsp;#=&gt; 3<div><br /></div><div>int('0b11', 2) #=&gt; 3</div>	
divmod	<div>divmod(a, b)</div>(a // b, a % b)<div><br /></div><div>divmod(5,2)</div><div>(2, 1)</div>	
what is the parameter for enumerate	enumerate(iterable, start=0)<div><br /></div><div>list(enumerate(range(7), start=3))</div><div><div>[(3, 0),</div><div>&nbsp;(4, 1),</div><div>&nbsp;(5, 2),</div><div>&nbsp;(6, 3),</div><div>&nbsp;(7, 4)]</div></div>	
What is the diff between equality and identity?	Equality means the 2 objects hold the same value.<div><br /></div><div>Identity means the 2 objects are the same object, aka reference the same place in&nbsp;the memory.</div>	
&nbsp;comparisons against None should always use	is&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>eg: if foo is not None:&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;pass</div>	
Refactor:<div><br /></div><div><div>is_generic_name = False</div><div>name = 'Tom'</div><div>if name == 'Tom' or name == 'Dick' or name == 'Harry':</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;is_generic_name = True</div></div>	<div>name = 'Tom'</div><div>is_generic_name = name in ('Tom', 'Dick', 'Harry')</div>	
write a function that joins a iterator into a string<div><br /></div><div>func(['f', 'o', 'o']) -&gt; &nbsp;'foo'</div>	cat = ''.join &nbsp;# Function to concatenate strings together.<div><br /></div><div>cat(['f', 'o', 'o'])</div>	
MRO	Method Resolution Order<div><br /></div><div>returns a list of types the class is derived from, in the order they are searched for methods</div>	
super	Return a proxy object&nbsp;<div>that delegates method calls to a parent or sibling class of type.&nbsp;</div><div><br /></div><div>This is useful for accessing inherited methods that have been overridden in a class.</div>	
Does regex.py accept strings, lists, or buffers?	strings and buffers	
Why is memoryview used?	handle parts of very large objects	
<div>v = memoryview(b'abcefg')</div><div><br /></div><div>v[1]</div>	98	
v = memoryview(b'abcefg')<div><br /></div><div>v[1:4]</div>	&lt;memory at 0x7f3ddc9f4350&gt;	
<div>v = memoryview(b'abcefg')</div><div><br /></div>bytes(v[1:4])	b'bce'	
Linear algebra functions	scipy.linalg	
Find the inverse of a square matrix	scipy.linalg.inv()	
Solve a linear system of equation	scipy.linalg.solve()	
Solve a banded linear system	scipy.linalg.solve_banded()	
Solve a Hermitian or symmetric banded system	scipy.linalg.solveh_banded()	
Solve a triangular matrix	scipy.linalg.solve_triangular()	
Find the determinant of a square matrix	scipy.linalg.det()	
Matrix and vector norm	scipy.linalg.norm()	
Solve a linear least-squares problem	scipy.linalg.lstsq()	
Pseudo-inverse (Moore-Penrose) using lstsq	scipy.linalg.pinv()	
Pseudo-inverse using svd	scipy.linalg.pinv2()	
Pseudo-inverse of hermitian matrix	scipy.linalg.pinvh()	
Kronecker product of two arrays	<div><br /></div><div>scipy.linalg.kron()</div>	
Construct a lower-triangular matrix from a given matrix	scipy.linalg.tril()	
Construct an upper-triangular matrix from a given matrix	scipy.linalg.triu()	
Solve an orthogonal Procrustes problem	scipy.linalg.orthogonal_procrustes()	
Given this generator, get 10th value<div><br /></div><div><div>def fib_gen():</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; a, b = 1, 1</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; while True:</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; yield a</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; a, b = b, a + bv</div></div>	<div># Easy to read but make entire list in memory</div>list(islice(fib_gen(), 10))[-1]&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div># Harder to read but more efficent</div><div><div>n = 10</div><div>islice(fib_gen(), n, n+1).next()</div></div>	
package for optimisation	PuLP	
immutable data structures	Pyrsistent	
toolz	a set of utility functions for iterators, functions, and dictionaries.&nbsp;<div><br /></div><div>extend the standard libraries itertools and functools&nbsp;</div>	
What is Python's stack depth limit, aka limit to recursion?	1000<div><br /></div><div># Change stack depth limit</div><div>sys.setrecursionlimit(1001)</div>	
Create a class that when called adds n to the base of&nbsp;	"<div>class Adder(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; ""A class that creates callable adder instances""</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __init__(self):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self.n = 5</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __call__(self, m):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return self.n + m</div>"	
"<div>Refactor to make function (hint: use a closure):</div><div><br /></div><div>class Adder(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; ""A class that creates callable adder instances""</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __init__(self):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self.n = 5</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __call__(self, m):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return self.n + m</div>"	<div>def make_adder(n):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def adder(m):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return m + n</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; return adder</div>	
In general, a descriptor is an object attribute with “binding behavior”, one whose attribute access has been ______________.<div><br /></div><div>Those methods are ____________________.</div><div>If any of those methods are defined for an object, it is said to be a descriptor.</div>	overridden by methods in the descriptor protocol<div><br /></div><div>__get__(), __set__(), and __delete__()</div>	
Create a Car object with @property decorator to set speed	"<div>class Car(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def __init__(self):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self._speed = 100</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; @property</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def speed(self):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; print(""Speed is"", self._speed)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return self._speed</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; @speed.setter</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def speed(self, value):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; print(""Setting to"", value)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; self._speed = value</div><div><br /></div><div>car = Car()</div><div>car.speed = 80</div><div>car.speed</div>"	
@staticmethod	"neither self (the object instance) nor &nbsp;cls (the class) is implicitly passed as the first argument.<div><br /></div><div>They behave like plain functions except that you can call them from an instance or the class</div><div><br /></div><div><div>import math</div><div>class RightTriangle(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; ""Class used solely as namespace for related functions""</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; @staticmethod</div><div>def hypotenuse(a, b):</div><div>return math.sqrt(a**2 + b**2)</div></div>"	
When is a good time to use static methods?	"Group functions which have some logical connection with a class to the class.<div><br /></div><div><div>import math</div><div>class RightTriangle(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; ""Class used solely as namespace for related functions""</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; @staticmethod</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def hypotenuse(a, b):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return math.sqrt(a**2 + b**2)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; @staticmethod</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def sin(a, b):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return a / RightTriangle.hypotenuse(a, b)</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; @staticmethod</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def cos(a, b):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return b / RightTriangle.hypotenuse(a, b)</div></div>"	
Refactor code to make run<div><br /></div><div><div>import functools, operator</div><div><br /></div><div>class Math(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def product(*nums):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return functools.reduce(operator.mul, nums)</div></div><div><br /></div><div>Math.product(3,4,5) #=&gt; 60</div><div><br /></div><div>m = Math()</div><div>m.product(3,4,5) #=&gt; 60</div>	<div><div><div>class Math(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; def product(*nums):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; return functools.reduce(operator.mul, nums)</div></div></div>	
Add attribute to existing class<div><br /></div><div>class Car(object):</div><div>&nbsp; &nbsp;pass</div>	<div>car = Car</div><div>setattr(car, 'name', 'Red Dragon')</div><div><br /></div><div>car.name #=&gt;&nbsp;'Red Dragon'</div>	
Iterators are _________ rather than realized collections	lazy sequences
